Name: Denoising Auto Encoder
Description: Denoising autoencoders (DAEs) are neural networks trained to reconstruct the original undistorted input from a partially corrupted input, aiming to clean or denoise the corrupted input.
Layers comment: Layers: Noisy Input, Hidden, Matched Output-Input

Name: Deep Convolutional Inverse Graphics Network
Description: A deep convolutional inverse graphics network (DC-IGN) learns interpretable image representations disentangled for transformations like out-of-plane rotations and lighting variations. It consists of convolution and de-convolution layers and is trained using the stochastic gradient variational Bayes (SGVB) algorithm.
Informal layers list: Input, Kernel, Convolutional/Pool, Probabilistic Hidden, Convolutional/Pool, Kernel, Output
Layers comment: Layers: Input, Kernel, Convolutional/Pool, Probabilistic Hidden, Convolutional/Pool, Kernel, Output

Name: Sparse Auto Encoder
Description: Sparse autoencoders have more hidden units than inputs but constrain only a few hidden units to be active at once, forcing the model to capture unique statistical features of the training data.

Name: Variational Auto Encoder
Description: A variational autoencoder (VAE) is a type of artificial neural network used for unsupervised learning. It consists of an encoder, which maps input data to a latent space, and a decoder, which reconstructs the input data from the latent space. Unlike traditional autoencoders, VAEs impose a probabilistic structure on the latent space, enabling them to generate new data samples by sampling from the learned latent distribution. This probabilistic approach allows VAEs to learn smooth and meaningful latent representations, making them useful for tasks such as data generation, anomaly detection, and semi-supervised learning.
Layers comment: Layers: Input, Probabilistic Hidden, Matched Output-Input

Name: Deep Neural Network
Description: A deep neural network (DNN) is a type of artificial neural network (ANN) characterized by multiple hidden layers between the input and output layers. Each layer consists of interconnected neurons that process and transmit information. DNNs can model complex patterns and representations in data through their hierarchical structure, where each layer extracts increasingly abstract features from the input. DNNs are widely used in various applications, including image and speech recognition, natural language processing, and more, due to their ability to learn and generalize from large amounts of data.

Name: Feedback Network
Description: A feedback network iteratively refines its representations based on feedback from previous iterations' outputs.

Name: Perceptron
Description: A perceptron is a supervised learning algorithm for binary classification, deciding if an input belongs to a class using a linear predictor function that combines weights with the feature vector.

Name: word2vec-CBOW
Description: In the continuous bag-of-words (CBOW) architecture, the model predicts the current word from a window of surrounding context words, ignoring the order of context words.

Name: word2vec-SkipGram
Description: In the continuous skip-gram architecture, the model predicts surrounding context words from the current word, giving more weight to nearby context words than distant ones.

Name: Restricted Boltzmann Machine
Description: A restricted Boltzmann machine (RBM) is a generative stochastic neural network that learns the probability distribution of its input data.

Name: Deep Convolutional Network
Description: A deep convolutional network (CNN) is an artificial neural network used to analyze visual imagery, utilizing shared-weight architecture and translation-equivariant feature maps.
Layers comment: Layers: Input, Kernel, Convolutional/Pool, Hidden, Output

Name: Deep Feed-Forward Network
Description: A deep feedforward neural network processes information in one direction—from input nodes through hidden nodes to output nodes—without cycles or loops.

Name: Deconvolutional Network
Description: Deconvolutional networks allow unsupervised construction of hierarchical image representations for tasks such as denoising and feature extraction for object recognition.

Name: Graph Convolutional Network
Description: A graph convolutional network (GCN) operates directly on graph structures, utilizing their structural information for tasks like node classification and graph clustering.

Name: Recurrent Neural Network
Description: A recurrent neural network (RNN) has connections forming a directed graph along a temporal sequence, enabling dynamic temporal behavior.

Name: Recursive Neural Network
Description: A recursive neural network applies the same set of weights recursively over structured input to generate structured or scalar predictions.

Name: Residual Neural Network
Description: A residual neural network (ResNet) employs skip connections to bypass certain layers, facilitating the learning of residual functions.
Informal layers list: Input, Weight, BN, ReLU, Weight, BN, Addition, ReLU
Layers comment: Layers: Input, Weight, BN, ReLU, Weight, BN, Addition, ReLU

Name: Transformer Network
Description: A transformer network utilizes attention mechanisms to weigh the significance of each part of the input data, widely used in natural language processing (NLP) and computer vision (CV).

Name: Extreme Learning Machine
Description: Extreme learning machines are feedforward neural networks with randomly assigned hidden node parameters that are not updated, learning output weights in a single step.

Name: Radial Basis Network
Description: Radial basis function networks use radial basis functions as activation functions, effective for pattern recognition and interpolation.

Name: Neural Turing Machine Network
Description: A neural Turing machine (NTM) combines neural network pattern matching with the algorithmic power of programmable computers, using attention mechanisms to interact with external memory for tasks like copying, sorting, and associative recall.
Layers comment: Layers: Input, Hidden, Spiking Hidden, Output

Name: Graph Convolutional Policy Network
Description: A graph convolutional policy network (GCPN) generates goal-directed graphs using a graph convolutional network and reinforcement learning, optimizing for domain-specific rewards and adversarial loss
Layers comment: Layers: Input, Hidden, Hidden, Policy, Output

Name: Gated Recurrent Unit
Description: Gated recurrent units (GRUs) are a gating mechanism in recurrent neural networks, similar to LSTMs but with fewer parameters and no output gate.

Name: Artificial Neural Network
Description: An artificial neural network (ANN) is based on a collection of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, modeled after biological neurons, with connections transmitting signals processed by non-linear functions.

Name: Kohonen Network
Description: A self-organizing map (SOM) or Kohonen network is an unsupervised machine learning technique producing a low-dimensional representation of high-dimensional data, preserving topological structure.

Name: Liquid State Machine Network
Description: A liquid state machine (LSM) is a type of reservoir computer using a spiking neural network, with recurrently connected nodes turning time-varying input into spatio-temporal activation patterns.

Name: Markov Chain
Description: A Markov chain is a stochastic model describing a sequence of possible events where the probability of each event depends only on the previous event's state.

Name: Symmetrically Connected Network
Description: Symmetrically connected networks are a type of recurrent neural network where connections between units are symmetrical, meaning they have equal weights in both directions. This structure allows the network to maintain consistent information flow and equilibrium.

Name: Support Vector Machine
Description: Support vector machines (SVMs) are supervised learning models for classification and regression analysis, mapping training examples to points in space to maximize the gap between categories.

Name: Unsupervised Pretrained Network
Description: Unsupervised pre-training initializes a discriminative neural net from one trained using an unsupervised criterion, aiding in optimization and overfitting issues.

Name: Echo State Network
Description: An echo state network (ESN) is a type of reservoir computer with a recurrent neural network and a sparsely connected hidden layer, learning output neuron weights to produce temporal patterns.

Name: Long Short Term Memory
Description: Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks are artificial recurrent neural networks with feedback connections, processing entire sequences of data for tasks like handwriting and speech recognition.

Name: Boltzmann Machine Network
Synomyms: BM|stochastic Hopfield network with hidden units|Sherrington–Kirkpatrick model with external field|stochastic Ising-Lenz-Little model
Description: A Boltzmann machine is a type of stochastic recurrent neural network and Markov random field, translated from statistical physics for use in cognitive science.

Name: Hopfield Network
Synomyms: HN|Ising model of a neural network|Ising–Lenz–Little model
Description: A Hopfield network is a type of recurrent artificial neural network that serves as a content-addressable ("associative") memory system. It uses binary threshold nodes or continuous variables to store and recall memory patterns, providing a model for understanding human memory.

Name: Auto Encoder Network
Description: An autoencoder is an artificial neural network used for learning efficient codings of unlabeled data, training the network to ignore insignificant data and regenerate input from encoding.

Name: Deep Belief Network
Description: A deep belief network (DBN) is a generative graphical model composed of multiple layers of latent variables, learning to probabilistically reconstruct inputs and perform classification.
Informal layers list: Backfed Input, Probabilistic Hidden, Hidden, Matched Output-Input
Layers comment: Layers: Backfed Input, Probabilistic Hidden, Hidden, Matched Output-Input

Name: Generative Adversarial Network
Description: A generative adversarial network (GAN) is a machine learning framework where two neural networks contest in a game to generate new data with the same statistics as the training set.
Informal layers list: Backfed Input, Hidden, Matched Output-Input, Hidden, Matched Output-Input
Layers comment: Layers: Backfed Input, Hidden, Matched Output-Input, Hidden, Matched Output-Input

Name: node2vec-CBOW
Description: In the continuous bag-of-words architecture, the model predicts the current node from a window of surrounding context nodes, with the order of context nodes not influencing prediction.

Name: node2vec-SkipGram
Description: In the continuous skip-gram architecture, the model uses the current node to predict the surrounding window of context nodes, weighing nearby context nodes more heavily than distant ones.

Name: Bayesian Network
Description: A probabilistic graphical model representing variables and their conditional dependencies via a directed acyclic graph (DAG).

Name: Contrastive Learning
Description: Contrastive learning is a self-supervised learning approach in which the model learns to distinguish between similar and dissimilar pairs of data samples. By maximizing the similarity between positive pairs (similar samples) and minimizing the similarity between negative pairs (dissimilar samples), the model learns to capture meaningful representations of the data. This method is particularly effective for representation learning and is widely used in tasks such as image classification, clustering, and retrieval. Contrastive learning techniques often employ loss functions such as the contrastive loss or the triplet loss to achieve these objectives.

Name: Continual Learning
Description: Learning a model for sequential tasks without forgetting knowledge from preceding tasks, with no access to old task data during new task training.

Name: Federated Learning
Description: Training an algorithm across multiple decentralized edge devices or servers holding local data samples without exchanging them.

Name: Deep Active Learning
Description: Combining deep learning and active learning to maximize model performance gain while annotating the fewest samples possible.

Name: One-shot Learning
Description: Classifying objects from one or only a few examples.

Name: Generalized Few-shot Learning
Description: Learning novel classes from few samples per class, preventing catastrophic forgetting of base classes and ensuring classifier calibration.

Name: Incremenetal Few-shot Learning
Description: Training a network on a base set of classes and then presenting it with novel classes, each with few labeled examples.

Name: Metric Learning
Description: Learning a representation function that maps objects into an embedded space.

Name: Multimodal Deep Learning
Description: Creating models that process and link information using various modalities.

Name: Deep Transfer Learning
Description: Relaxing the hypothesis that training data must be independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) with test data to address insufficient training data.

Name: Zero-shot Learning
Description: Predicting classes at test time from classes not observed during training.

Name: Representation Learning
Description: Discovering representations required for feature detection or classification from raw data.

Name: Sparse Learning
Description: Finding sparse representations of input data as a linear combination of basic elements and identifying those elements.

Name: Layer
Description: A structure or network topology in a deep learning model that takes information from previous layers and passes it to the next layer.

Name: Network
Description: A system of interconnected nodes or entities for communication, computation, or data exchange.

Name: Function
Description: A mathematical rule that gives the value of a dependent variable corresponding to specified values of one or more independent variables.

Name: ELU Function
Description: The exponential linear unit (ELU) with alpha > 0 is: x if x > 0 and alpha * (exp(x) - 1) if x < 0 The ELU hyperparameter alpha controls the value to which an ELU saturates for negative net inputs. ELUs diminish the vanishing gradient effect. ELUs have negative values which pushes the mean of the activations closer to zero. Mean activations that are closer to zero enable faster Learning as they bring the gradient closer to the natural gradient. ELUs saturate to a negative value when the argument gets smaller. Saturation means a small derivative which decreases the variation and the information that is propagated to the next layer.

Name: Exponential Function
Description: The exponential function is a mathematical function denoted by f(x)=exp or e^{x}.

Name: GELU Function
Description: Gaussian error linear unit (GELU) computes x * P(X <= x), where P(X) ~ N(0, 1). The (GELU) nonlinearity weights inputs by their value, rather than gates inputs by their sign as in ReLU.

Name: Hard Sigmoid Function
Description: A faster approximation of the sigmoid activation. Piecewise linear approximation of the sigmoid function. Ref: 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hard_sigmoid'

Name: Linear Function
Description: A linear function has the form f(x) = a + bx.

Name: ReLU Function
Description: The ReLU activation function returns: max(x, 0), the element-wise maximum of 0 and the input tensor.

Name: SELU Function
Description: The SELU activation function multiplies scale (> 1) with the output of the ELU function to ensure a slope larger than one for positive inputs.

Name: Sigmoid Function
Description: Applies the sigmoid activation function sigmoid(x) = 1 / (1 + exp(-x)). For small values (<-5), sigmoid returns a value close to zero, and for large values (>5) the result of the function gets close to 1. Sigmoid is equivalent to a 2-element Softmax, where the second element is assumed to be zero. The sigmoid function always returns a value between 0 and 1.

Name: Softmax Function
Description: The elements of the output vector are in range (0, 1) and sum to 1. Each vector is handled independently. The axis argument sets which axis of the input the function is applied along. Softmax is often used as the activation for the last layer of a classification network because the result could be interpreted as a probability distribution. The softmax of each vector x is computed as exp(x) / tf.reduce_sum(exp(x)). The input values in are the log-odds of the resulting probability.

Name: Softplus Function
Description: softplus(x) = log(exp(x) + 1)

Name: Softsign Function
Description: softsign(x) = x / (abs(x) + 1)

Name: Swish Function
Description: x*sigmoid(x). It is a smooth, non-monotonic function that consistently matches or outperforms ReLU on deep networks, it is unbounded above and bounded below.

Name: Tanh Function
Description: Hyperbolic tangent activation function.

Name: Convolutional Layer
Description: A convolutional layer is the main building block of a CNN. It contains a set of filters (or kernels), parameters of which are to be learned throughout the training. The size of the filters is usually smaller than the actual image. Each filter convolves with the image and creates an activation map.

Name: Hidden Layer
Description: A hidden layer is located between the input and output of the algorithm, in which the function applies weights to the inputs and directs them through an activation function as the output. In short, the hidden layers perform nonlinear transformations of the inputs entered into the network. Hidden layers vary depending on the function of the neural network, and similarly, the layers may vary depending on their associated weights.

Name: Input Layer
Description: The input layer of a neural network is composed of artificial input neurons, and brings the initial data into the system for further processing by subsequent layers of artificial neurons. The input layer is the very beginning of the workflow for the artificial neural network.

Name: Output Layer
Description: The output layer in an artificial neural network is the last layer of neurons that produces given outputs for the program. Though they are made much like other artificial neurons in the neural network, output layer neurons may be built or observed in a different way, given that they are the last “actor” nodes on the network.

Name: Recurrent Layer
Description: A layer of an RNB, composed of recurrent units and with the number of which is the hidden size of the layer.

Name: Pooling Layer
Description: Pooling layers serve the dual purposes of mitigating the sensitivity of convolutional layers to location and of spatially downsampling representations.

Name: Locally-connected Layer
Description: The LocallyConnected1D layer works similarly to the Convolution1D layer, except that weights are unshared, that is, a different set of filters is applied at each different patch of the input.

Name: Regularization Layer
Description: Regularizers allow you to apply penalties on layer parameters or layer activity during optimization. These penalties are summed into the loss function that the network optimizes. Regularization penalties are applied on a per-layer basis.

Name: Reshaping Layer
Description: Reshape layers are used to change the shape of the input.

Name: Merging Layer
Description: A layer used to merge a list of inputs.

Name: Preprocessing Layer
Description: A layer that performs data preprocessing operations.

Name: Text Preprocessing Layer
Description: A layer that performs text data preprocessing operations.

Name: Numerical Features Preprocessing Layer
Description: A layer that performs numerical data preprocessing operations.

Name: Categorical Features Preprocessing Layer
Description: A layer that performs categorical data preprocessing operations.

Name: Image Preprocessing Layer
Description: A layer that performs image data preprocessing operations.

Name: Image Augmentation Layer
Description: A layer that performs image data preprocessing augmentations.

Name: AbstractRNNCell
Description: Abstract object representing an RNN cell. This is the base class for implementing RNN cells with custom behavior.

Name: Activation Layer
Description: Applies an activation function to an output.

Name: ActivityRegularization Layer
Description: Layer that applies an update to the cost function based input activity.

Name: Add Layer
Description: Layer that adds a list of inputs. It takes as input a list of tensors, all of the same shape, and returns a single tensor (also of the same shape).

Name: AdditiveAttention Layer
Description: Additive attention layer, a.k.a. Bahdanau-style attention.

Name: AlphaDropout Layer
Description: Applies Alpha Dropout to the input. Alpha Dropout is a Dropout that keeps mean and variance of inputs to their original values, in order to ensure the self-normalizing property even after this dropout. Alpha Dropout fits well to Scaled Exponential Linear Units by randomly setting activations to the negative saturation value.

Name: Attention Layer
Description: Dot-product attention layer, a.k.a. Luong-style attention.

Name: Average Layer
Description: Layer that averages a list of inputs element-wise. It takes as input a list of tensors, all of the same shape, and returns a single tensor (also of the same shape).

Name: AveragePooling1D Layer
Description: Average pooling for temporal data. Downsamples the input representation by taking the average value over the window defined by pool_size. The window is shifted by strides. The resulting output when using "valid" padding option has a shape of: output_shape = (input_shape - pool_size + 1) / strides). The resulting output shape when using the "same" padding option is: output_shape = input_shape / strides.

Name: AveragePooling2D Layer
Description: Average pooling operation for spatial data. Downsamples the input along its spatial dimensions (height and width) by taking the average value over an input window (of size defined by pool_size) for each channel of the input. The window is shifted by strides along each dimension. The resulting output when using "valid" padding option has a shape (number of rows or columns) of: output_shape = math.floor((input_shape - pool_size) / strides) + 1 (when input_shape >= pool_size). The resulting output shape when using the "same" padding option is: output_shape = math.floor((input_shape - 1) / strides) + 1.

Name: AveragePooling3D Layer
Description: Average pooling operation for 3D data (spatial or spatio-temporal). Downsamples the input along its spatial dimensions (depth, height, and width) by taking the average value over an input window (of size defined by pool_size) for each channel of the input. The window is shifted by strides along each dimension.

Name: BatchNormalization Layer
Description: Layer that normalizes its inputs. Batch normalization applies a transformation that maintains the mean output close to 0 and the output standard deviation close to 1. Importantly, batch normalization works differently during training and during inference. During training (i.e. when using fit() or when calling the layer/model with the argument training=True), the layer normalizes its output using the mean and standard deviation of the current batch of inputs. That is to say, for each channel being normalized, the layer returns gamma * (batch - mean(batch)) / sqrt(var(batch) + epsilon) + beta, where: epsilon is small constant (configurable as part of the constructor arguments), gamma is a learned scaling factor (initialized as 1), which can be disabled by passing scale=False to the constructor. beta is a learned offset factor (initialized as 0), which can be disabled by passing center=False to the constructor. During inference (i.e. when using evaluate() or predict() or when calling the layer/model with the argument training=False (which is the default), the layer normalizes its output using a moving average of the mean and standard deviation of the batches it has seen during training. That is to say, it returns gamma * (batch - self.moving_mean) / sqrt(self.moving_var + epsilon) + beta. self.moving_mean and self.moving_var are non-trainable variables that are updated each time the layer in called in training mode, as such: moving_mean = moving_mean * momentum + mean(batch) * (1 - momentum) moving_var = moving_var * momentum + var(batch) * (1 - momentum).

Name: BatchNorm1D Layer
Description: Applies Batch Normalization over a 2D or 3D input as described in the paper Batch Normalization: Accelerating Deep Network Training by Reducing Internal Covariate Shift .

Name: BatchNorm2D Layer
Description: Applies Batch Normalization over a 4D input (a mini-batch of 2D inputs with additional channel dimension) as described in the paper Batch Normalization: Accelerating Deep Network Training by Reducing Internal Covariate Shift .

Name: BatchNorm3D Layer
Description: Applies Batch Normalization over a 5D input (a mini-batch of 3D inputs with additional channel dimension) as described in the paper Batch Normalization: Accelerating Deep Network Training by Reducing Internal Covariate Shift .

Name: LazyBatchNorm1D Layer
Description: A torch.nn.BatchNorm1d module with lazy initialization of the num_features argument of the BatchNorm1d that is inferred from the input.size(1).

Name: LazyBatchNorm2D Layer
Description: A torch.nn.BatchNorm2d module with lazy initialization of the num_features argument of the BatchNorm2d that is inferred from the input.size(1).

Name: LazyBatchNorm3D Layer
Description: A torch.nn.BatchNorm3d module with lazy initialization of the num_features argument of the BatchNorm3d that is inferred from the input.size(1).

Name: GroupNorm Layer
Description: Applies Group Normalization over a mini-batch of inputs as described in the paper Group Normalization

Name: SyncBatchNorm Layer
Description: Applies Batch Normalization over a N-Dimensional input (a mini-batch of [N-2]D inputs with additional channel dimension) as described in the paper Batch Normalization: Accelerating Deep Network Training by Reducing Internal Covariate Shift .

Name: InstanceNorm1d Layer
Description: Applies Instance Normalization over a 2D (unbatched) or 3D (batched) input as described in the paper Instance Normalization: The Missing Ingredient for Fast Stylization.

Name: InstanceNorm2d
Description: Applies Instance Normalization over a 4D input (a mini-batch of 2D inputs with additional channel dimension) as described in the paper Instance Normalization: The Missing Ingredient for Fast Stylization.

Name: InstanceNorm3d Layer
Description: Applies Instance Normalization over a 5D input (a mini-batch of 3D inputs with additional channel dimension) as described in the paper Instance Normalization: The Missing Ingredient for Fast Stylization.

Name: LazyInstanceNorm1d Layer
Description: A torch.nn.InstanceNorm1d module with lazy initialization of the num_features argument of the InstanceNorm1d that is inferred from the input.size(1).

Name: LazyInstanceNorm2d Layer
Description: A torch.nn.InstanceNorm2d module with lazy initialization of the num_features argument of the InstanceNorm2d that is inferred from the input.size(1).

Name: LazyInstanceNorm3d Layer
Description: A torch.nn.InstanceNorm3d module with lazy initialization of the num_features argument of the InstanceNorm3d that is inferred from the input.size(1).

Name: LayerNorm Layer
Description: Applies Layer Normalization over a mini-batch of inputs as described in the paper Layer Normalization

Name: LocalResponseNorm Layer
Description: Applies local response normalization over an input signal composed of several input planes, where channels occupy the second dimension.

Name: Bidirectional Layer
Description: Bidirectional wrapper for RNNs.

Name: CategoryEncoding Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which encodes integer features. This layer provides options for condensing data into a categorical encoding when the total number of tokens are known in advance. It accepts integer values as inputs, and it outputs a dense or sparse representation of those inputs. For integer inputs where the total number of tokens is not known, use tf.keras.layers.IntegerLookup instead.

Name: CenterCrop Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which crops images. This layers crops the central portion of the images to a target size. If an image is smaller than the target size, it will be resized and cropped so as to return the largest possible window in the image that matches the target aspect ratio. Input pixel values can be of any range (e.g. [0., 1.) or [0, 255]) and of interger or floating point dtype. By default, the layer will output floats.

Name: Concatenate Layer
Description: Layer that concatenates a list of inputs. It takes as input a list of tensors, all of the same shape except for the concatenation axis, and returns a single tensor that is the concatenation of all inputs.

Name: ConvLSTM1D Layer
Description: 1D Convolutional LSTM. Similar to an LSTM layer, but the input transformations and recurrent transformations are both convolutional.

Name: ConvLSTM2D Layer
Description: 2D Convolutional LSTM. Similar to an LSTM layer, but the input transformations and recurrent transformations are both convolutional.

Name: ConvLSTM3D Layer
Description: 3D Convolutional LSTM. Similar to an LSTM layer, but the input transformations and recurrent transformations are both convolutional.

Name: Convolution1D Layer
Description: 1D convolution layer (e.g. temporal convolution).

Name: Convolution1DTranspose Layer
Description: Transposed convolution layer (sometimes called Deconvolution). The need for transposed convolutions generally arises from the desire to use a transformation going in the opposite direction of a normal convolution, i.e., from something that has the shape of the output of some convolution to something that has the shape of its input while maintaining a connectivity pattern that is compatible with said convolution. When using this layer as the first layer in a model, provide the keyword argument input_shape (tuple of integers or None, does not include the sample axis), e.g. input_shape=(128, 3) for data with 128 time steps and 3 channels.

Name: Convolution2D Layer
Description: 2D convolution layer (e.g. spatial convolution over images). This layer creates a convolution kernel that is convolved with the layer input to produce a tensor of outputs. If use_bias is True, a bias vector is created and added to the outputs. Finally, if activation is not None, it is applied to the outputs as well. When using this layer as the first layer in a model, provide the keyword argument input_shape (tuple of integers or None, does not include the sample axis), e.g. input_shape=(128, 128, 3) for 128x128 RGB pictures in data_format="channels_last". You can use None when a dimension has variable size.

Name: Convolution2DTranspose Layer
Description: Transposed convolution layer (sometimes called Deconvolution).

Name: Convolution3D Layer
Description: 3D convolution layer (e.g. spatial convolution over volumes). This layer creates a convolution kernel that is convolved with the layer input to produce a tensor of outputs. If use_bias is True, a bias vector is created and added to the outputs. Finally, if activation is not None, it is applied to the outputs as well. When using this layer as the first layer in a model, provide the keyword argument input_shape (tuple of integers or None, does not include the sample axis), e.g. input_shape=(128, 128, 128, 1) for 128x128x128 volumes with a single channel, in data_format="channels_last".

Name: Convolution3DTranspose Layer
Description: Transposed convolution layer (sometimes called Deconvolution). The need for transposed convolutions generally arises from the desire to use a transformation going in the opposite direction of a normal convolution, i.e., from something that has the shape of the output of some convolution to something that has the shape of its input while maintaining a connectivity pattern that is compatible with said convolution. When using this layer as the first layer in a model, provide the keyword argument input_shape (tuple of integers or None, does not include the sample axis), e.g. input_shape=(128, 128, 128, 3) for a 128x128x128 volume with 3 channels if data_format="channels_last".

Name: Cropping1D Layer
Description: Cropping layer for 1D input (e.g. temporal sequence). It crops along the time dimension (axis 1).

Name: Cropping2D Layer
Description: Cropping layer for 2D input (e.g. picture). It crops along spatial dimensions, i.e. height and width.

Name: Cropping3D Layer
Description: Cropping layer for 3D data (e.g. spatial or spatio-temporal).

Name: Dense Layer
Description: Just your regular densely-connected NN layer.

Name: DenseFeatures Layer
Description: A layer that produces a dense Tensor based on given feature_columns. Generally a single example in training data is described with FeatureColumns. At the first layer of the model, this column oriented data should be converted to a single Tensor. This layer can be called multiple times with different features. This is the V2 version of this layer that uses name_scopes to create variables instead of variable_scopes. But this approach currently lacks support for partitioned variables. In that case, use the V1 version instead.

Name: DepthwiseConv1D Layer
Description: Depthwise 1D convolution. Depthwise convolution is a type of convolution in which each input channel is convolved with a different kernel (called a depthwise kernel). You can understand depthwise convolution as the first step in a depthwise separable convolution. It is implemented via the following steps: Split the input into individual channels. Convolve each channel with an individual depthwise kernel with depth_multiplier output channels. Concatenate the convolved outputs along the channels axis. Unlike a regular 1D convolution, depthwise convolution does not mix information across different input channels. The depth_multiplier argument determines how many filter are applied to one input channel. As such, it controls the amount of output channels that are generated per input channel in the depthwise step.

Name: DepthwiseConv2D Layer
Description: Depthwise 2D convolution.

Name: Discretization Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which buckets continuous features by ranges.

Name: Dot Layer
Description: Layer that computes a dot product between samples in two tensors. E.g. if applied to a list of two tensors a and b of shape (batch_size, n), the output will be a tensor of shape (batch_size, 1) where each entry i will be the dot product between a[i] and b[i].

Name: Dropout Layer
Description: Applies Dropout to the input. The Dropout layer randomly sets input units to 0 with a frequency of rate at each step during training time, which helps prevent overfitting. Inputs not set to 0 are scaled up by 1/(1 - rate) such that the sum over all inputs is unchanged. Note that the Dropout layer only applies when training is set to True such that no values are dropped during inference. When using model.fit, training will be appropriately set to True automatically, and in other contexts, you can set the kwarg explicitly to True when calling the layer. (This is in contrast to setting trainable=False for a Dropout layer. trainable does not affect the layer's behavior, as Dropout does not have any variables/weights that can be frozen during training.)

Name: ELU Layer
Description: Exponential Linear Unit.

Name: Embedding Layer
Description: Turns positive integers (indexes) into dense vectors of fixed size.

Name: Flatten Layer
Description: Flattens the input. Does not affect the batch size.

Name: GRU Layer
Description: Gated Recurrent Unit - Cho et al. 2014. Based on available runtime hardware and constraints, this layer will choose different implementations (cuDNN-based or pure-TensorFlow) to maximize the performance. If a GPU is available and all the arguments to the layer meet the requirement of the cuDNN kernel (see below for details), the layer will use a fast cuDNN implementation. The requirements to use the cuDNN implementation are: activation == tanh, recurrent_activation == sigmoid, recurrent_dropout == 0, unroll is False, use_bias is True, reset_after is True. Inputs, if use masking, are strictly right-padded. Eager execution is enabled in the outermost context. There are two variants of the GRU implementation. The default one is based on v3 and has reset gate applied to hidden state before matrix multiplication. The other one is based on original and has the order reversed. The second variant is compatible with CuDNNGRU (GPU-only) and allows inference on CPU. Thus it has separate biases for kernel and recurrent_kernel. To use this variant, set reset_after=True and recurrent_activation='sigmoid'.

Name: GRUCell Layer
Description: Cell class for the GRU layer. This class processes one step within the whole time sequence input, whereas tf.keras.layer.GRU processes the whole sequence.

Name: GaussianDropout Layer
Description: Apply multiplicative 1-centered Gaussian noise. As it is a regularization layer, it is only active at training time.

Name: GaussianNoise Layer
Description: Apply additive zero-centered Gaussian noise. This is useful to mitigate overfitting (you could see it as a form of random data augmentation). Gaussian Noise (GS) is a natural choice as corruption process for real valued inputs. As it is a regularization layer, it is only active at training time.

Name: GlobalAveragePooling1D Layer
Description: Global average pooling operation for temporal data.

Name: GlobalAveragePooling2D Layer
Description: Global average pooling operation for spatial data.

Name: GlobalAveragePooling3D Layer
Description: Global Average pooling operation for 3D data.

Name: GlobalMaxPooling1D Layer
Description: Global max pooling operation for 1D temporal data.

Name: GlobalMaxPooling2D Layer
Description: Global max pooling operation for spatial data.

Name: GlobalMaxPooling3D Layer
Description: Global Max pooling operation for 3D data.

Name: Hashing Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which hashes and bins categorical features. This layer transforms categorical inputs to hashed output. It element-wise converts a ints or strings to ints in a fixed range. The stable hash function uses tensorflow::ops::Fingerprint to produce the same output consistently across all platforms. This layer uses FarmHash64 by default, which provides a consistent hashed output across different platforms and is stable across invocations, regardless of device and context, by mixing the input bits thoroughly. If you want to obfuscate the hashed output, you can also pass a random salt argument in the constructor. In that case, the layer will use the SipHash64 hash function, with the salt value serving as additional input to the hash function.

Name: InputLayer Layer
Description: Layer to be used as an entry point into a Network (a graph of layers).

Name: InputSpec Layer
Description: Specifies the rank, dtype and shape of every input to a layer. Layers can expose (if appropriate) an input_spec attribute: an instance of InputSpec, or a nested structure of InputSpec instances (one per input tensor). These objects enable the layer to run input compatibility checks for input structure, input rank, input shape, and input dtype. A None entry in a shape is compatible with any dimension, a None shape is compatible with any shape.

Name: IntegerLookup Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which maps integer features to contiguous ranges.

Name: LSTM Layer
Description: Long Short-Term Memory layer - Hochreiter 1997. Based on available runtime hardware and constraints, this layer will choose different implementations (cuDNN-based or pure-TensorFlow) to maximize the performance. If a GPU is available and all the arguments to the layer meet the requirement of the cuDNN kernel (see below for details), the layer will use a fast cuDNN implementation. The requirements to use the cuDNN implementation are: 1. activation == tanh, 2. recurrent_activation == sigmoid, 3. recurrent_dropout == 0, 4. unroll is False, 5. use_bias is True, 6. Inputs, if use masking, are strictly right-padded, 7. Eager execution is enabled in the outermost context.

Name: LSTMCell Layer
Description: Cell class for the LSTM layer.

Name: Lambda Layer
Description: Wraps arbitrary expressions as a Layer object.

Name: Layer Layer
Description: This is the class from which all layers inherit. A layer is a callable object that takes as input one or more tensors and that outputs one or more tensors. It involves computation, defined in the call() method, and a state (weight variables). State can be created in various places, at the convenience of the subclass implementer: in __init__(); in the optional build() method, which is invoked by the first __call__() to the layer, and supplies the shape(s) of the input(s), which may not have been known at initialization time; in the first invocation of call(), with some caveats discussed below. Users will just instantiate a layer and then treat it as a callable.

Name: LayerNormalization Layer
Description: Layer normalization layer (Ba et al., 2016). Normalize the activations of the previous layer for each given example in a batch independently, rather than across a batch like Batch Normalization. i.e. applies a transformation that maintains the mean activation within each example close to 0 and the activation standard deviation close to 1. Given a tensor inputs, moments are calculated and normalization is performed across the axes specified in axis.

Name: LeakyReLU Layer
Description: Leaky version of a Rectified Linear Unit.

Name: LocallyConnected1D Layer
Description: Locally-connected layer for 1D inputs. The LocallyConnected1D layer works similarly to the Conv1D layer, except that weights are unshared, that is, a different set of filters is applied at each different patch of the input.

Name: LocallyConnected2D Layer
Description: Locally-connected layer for 2D inputs. The LocallyConnected2D layer works similarly to the Conv2D layer, except that weights are unshared, that is, a different set of filters is applied at each different patch of the input.

Name: Masking Layer
Description: Masks a sequence by using a mask value to skip timesteps. For each timestep in the input tensor (dimension #1 in the tensor), if all values in the input tensor at that timestep are equal to mask_value, then the timestep will be masked (skipped) in all downstream layers (as long as they support masking). If any downstream layer does not support masking yet receives such an input mask, an exception will be raised.

Name: MaxPooling1D Layer
Description: Max pooling operation for 1D temporal data. Downsamples the input representation by taking the maximum value over a spatial window of size pool_size. The window is shifted by strides. The resulting output, when using the "valid" padding option, has a shape of: output_shape = (input_shape - pool_size + 1) / strides) The resulting output shape when using the "same" padding option is: output_shape = input_shape / strides.

Name: MaxPooling2D Layer
Description: Max pooling operation for 2D spatial data.

Name: MaxPooling3D Layer
Description: Max pooling operation for 3D data (spatial or spatio-temporal). Downsamples the input along its spatial dimensions (depth, height, and width) by taking the maximum value over an input window (of size defined by pool_size) for each channel of the input. The window is shifted by strides along each dimension.

Name: MaxUnpool1D Layer
Description: Computes a partial inverse of MaxPool1d.

Name: MaxUnpool2D Layer
Description: Computes a partial inverse of MaxPool2d.

Name: MaxUnpool3D Layer
Description: Computes a partial inverse of MaxPool3d.

Name: AvgPool1D Layer
Description: Applies a 1D average pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: AvgPool2D Layer
Description: Applies a 2D average pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: AvgPool3D Layer
Description: Applies a 3D average pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: FractionalMaxPool2D Layer
Description: Applies a 2D fractional max pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: FractionalMaxPool3D Layer
Description: Applies a 3D fractional max pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: LPPool1D Layer
Description: Applies a 1D power-average pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: LPPool2D Layer
Description: Applies a 2D power-average pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: AdaptiveMaxPool1D Layer
Description: Applies a 1D adaptive max pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: AdaptiveMaxPool2D Layer
Description: Applies a 2D adaptive max pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: AdaptiveMaxPool3D Layer
Description: Applies a 3D adaptive max pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: AdaptiveAvgPool1D Layer
Description: Applies a 1D adaptive average pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: AdaptiveAvgPool2D Layer
Description: Applies a 2D adaptive average pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: AdaptiveAvgPool3D Layer
Description: Applies a 3D adaptive average pooling over an input signal composed of several input planes.

Name: Maximum Layer
Description: Layer that computes the maximum (element-wise) a list of inputs. It takes as input a list of tensors, all of the same shape, and returns a single tensor (also of the same shape).

Name: Minimum Layer
Description: Layer that computes the minimum (element-wise) a list of inputs. It takes as input a list of tensors, all of the same shape, and returns a single tensor (also of the same shape).

Name: MultiHeadAttention Layer
Description: MultiHeadAttention layer. This is an implementation of multi-headed attention as described in the paper "Attention is all you Need" (Vaswani et al., 2017). If query, key, value are the same, then this is self-attention. Each timestep in query attends to the corresponding sequence in key, and returns a fixed-width vector.This layer first projects query, key and value. These are (effectively) a list of tensors of length num_attention_heads, where the corresponding shapes are (batch_size, <query dimensions>, key_dim), (batch_size, <key/value dimensions>, key_dim), (batch_size, <key/value dimensions>, value_dim).Then, the query and key tensors are dot-producted and scaled. These are softmaxed to obtain attention probabilities. The value tensors are then interpolated by these probabilities, then concatenated back to a single tensor. Finally, the result tensor with the last dimension as value_dim can take an linear projection and return. When using MultiHeadAttention inside a custom Layer, the custom Layer must implement build() and call MultiHeadAttention's _build_from_signature(). This enables weights to be restored correctly when the model is loaded.

Name: Multiply Layer
Description: Layer that multiplies (element-wise) a list of inputs. It takes as input a list of tensors, all of the same shape, and returns a single tensor (also of the same shape).

Name: Noise Dense Layer
Description: Noisy dense layer that injects random noise to the weights of dense layer. Noisy dense layers are fully connected layers whose weights and biases are augmented by factorised Gaussian noise. The factorised Gaussian noise is controlled through gradient descent by a second weights layer. A NoisyDense layer implements the operation: $$ \mathrm{NoisyDense}(x) = \mathrm{activation}(\mathrm{dot}(x, \mu + (\sigma \cdot \epsilon)) \mathrm{bias}) $$ where mu is the standard weights layer, epsilon is the factorised Gaussian noise, and delta is a second weights layer which controls epsilon.

Name: Normalization Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which normalizes continuous features.

Name: PReLU Layer
Description: Parametric Rectified Linear Unit.

Name: Permute Layer
Description: Permutes the dimensions of the input according to a given pattern. Useful e.g. connecting RNNs and convnets.

Name: RNN Layer
Description: Base class for recurrent layers.

Name: RandomBrightness Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which randomly adjusts brightness during training. This layer will randomly increase/reduce the brightness for the input RGB images. At inference time, the output will be identical to the input. Call the layer with training=True to adjust the brightness of the input. Note that different brightness adjustment factors will be apply to each the images in the batch.

Name: RandomContrast Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which randomly adjusts contrast during training. This layer will randomly adjust the contrast of an image or images by a random factor. Contrast is adjusted independently for each channel of each image during training. For each channel, this layer computes the mean of the image pixels in the channel and then adjusts each component x of each pixel to (x - mean) * contrast_factor + mean. Input pixel values can be of any range (e.g. [0., 1.) or [0, 255]) and in integer or floating point dtype. By default, the layer will output floats. The output value will be clipped to the range [0, 255], the valid range of RGB colors.

Name: RandomCrop Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which randomly crops images during training. During training, this layer will randomly choose a location to crop images down to a target size. The layer will crop all the images in the same batch to the same cropping location. At inference time, and during training if an input image is smaller than the target size, the input will be resized and cropped so as to return the largest possible window in the image that matches the target aspect ratio. If you need to apply random cropping at inference time, set training to True when calling the layer. Input pixel values can be of any range (e.g. [0., 1.) or [0, 255]) and of interger or floating point dtype. By default, the layer will output floats.

Name: RandomFlip Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which randomly flips images during training. This layer will flip the images horizontally and or vertically based on the mode attribute. During inference time, the output will be identical to input. Call the layer with training=True to flip the input. Input pixel values can be of any range (e.g. [0., 1.) or [0, 255]) and of interger or floating point dtype. By default, the layer will output floats.

Name: RandomHeight Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which randomly varies image height during training. This layer adjusts the height of a batch of images by a random factor. The input should be a 3D (unbatched) or 4D (batched) tensor in the "channels_last" image data format. Input pixel values can be of any range (e.g. [0., 1.) or [0, 255]) and of interger or floating point dtype. By default, the layer will output floats. By default, this layer is inactive during inference.

Name: RandomRotation Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which randomly rotates images during training.

Name: RandomTranslation Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which randomly translates images during training. This layer will apply random translations to each image during training, filling empty space according to fill_mode. aInput pixel values can be of any range (e.g. [0., 1.) or [0, 255]) and of interger or floating point dtype. By default, the layer will output floats.

Name: RandomWidth Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which randomly varies image width during training. This layer will randomly adjusts the width of a batch of images of a batch of images by a random factor. The input should be a 3D (unbatched) or 4D (batched) tensor in the "channels_last" image data format. Input pixel values can be of any range (e.g. [0., 1.) or [0, 255]) and of interger or floating point dtype. By default, the layer will output floats. By default, this layer is inactive during inference.

Name: RandomZoom Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which randomly zooms images during training. This layer will randomly zoom in or out on each axis of an image independently, filling empty space according to fill_mode.Input pixel values can be of any range (e.g. [0., 1.) or [0, 255]) and of interger or floating point dtype. By default, the layer will output floats.

Name: ReLU Layer
Description: Rectified Linear Unit activation function. With default values, it returns element-wise max(x, 0).

Name: RepeatVector Layer
Description: Repeats the input n times.

Name: Rescaling Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which rescales input values to a new range.

Name: Reshape Layer
Description: Layer that reshapes inputs into the given shape.

Name: Resizing Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which resizes images. This layer resizes an image input to a target height and width. The input should be a 4D (batched) or 3D (unbatched) tensor in "channels_last" format. Input pixel values can be of any range (e.g. [0., 1.) or [0, 255]) and of interger or floating point dtype. By default, the layer will output floats. This layer can be called on tf.RaggedTensor batches of input images of distinct sizes, and will resize the outputs to dense tensors of uniform size.

Name: SeparableConvolution1D Layer
Description: Depthwise separable 1D convolution. This layer performs a depthwise convolution that acts separately on channels, followed by a pointwise convolution that mixes channels. If use_bias is True and a bias initializer is provided, it adds a bias vector to the output. It then optionally applies an activation function to produce the final output.a

Name: SeparableConvolution2D Layer
Description: Depthwise separable 2D convolution. Separable convolutions consist of first performing a depthwise spatial convolution (which acts on each input channel separately) followed by a pointwise convolution which mixes the resulting output channels. The depth_multiplier argument controls how many output channels are generated per input channel in the depthwise step. Intuitively, separable convolutions can be understood as a way to factorize a convolution kernel into two smaller kernels, or as an extreme version of an Inception block.

Name: SimpleRNN Layer
Description: Fully-connected RNN where the output is to be fed back to input.

Name: SimpleRNNCell Layer
Description: Cell class for SimpleRNN. This class processes one step within the whole time sequence input, whereas tf.keras.layer.SimpleRNN processes the whole sequence.

Name: Softmax Layer
Description: Softmax activation function.

Name: SpatialDropout1D Layer
Description: Spatial 1D version of Dropout. This version performs the same function as Dropout, however, it drops entire 1D feature maps instead of individual elements. If adjacent frames within feature maps are strongly correlated (as is normally the case in early convolution layers) then regular dropout will not regularize the activations and will otherwise just result in an effective Learning rate decrease. In this case, SpatialDropout1D will help promote independence between feature maps and should be used instead.

Name: SpatialDropout2D Layer
Description: Spatial 2D version of Dropout. This version performs the same function as Dropout, however, it drops entire 2D feature maps instead of individual elements. If adjacent pixels within feature maps are strongly correlated (as is normally the case in early convolution layers) then regular dropout will not regularize the activations and will otherwise just result in an effective Learning rate decrease. In this case, SpatialDropout2D will help promote independence between feature maps and should be used instead.a

Name: SpatialDropout3D Layer
Description: Spatial 3D version of Dropout. This version performs the same function as Dropout, however, it drops entire 3D feature maps instead of individual elements. If adjacent voxels within feature maps are strongly correlated (as is normally the case in early convolution layers) then regular dropout will not regularize the activations and will otherwise just result in an effective Learning rate decrease. In this case, SpatialDropout3D will help promote independence between feature maps and should be used instead.

Name: StackedRNNCells Layer
Description: Wrapper allowing a stack of RNN cells to behave as a single cell. Used to implement efficient stacked RNNs.

Name: StringLookup Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which maps string features to integer indices.

Name: Subtract Layer
Description: Layer that subtracts two inputs. It takes as input a list of tensors of size 2, both of the same shape, and returns a single tensor, (inputs[0] - inputs[1]), also of the same shape.

Name: TextVectorization Layer
Description: A preprocessing layer which maps text features to integer sequences.

Name: ThresholdedReLU Layer
Description: Thresholded Rectified Linear Unit.

Name: TimeDistributed Layer
Description: This wrapper allows to apply a layer to every temporal slice of an input. Every input should be at least 3D, and the dimension of index one of the first input will be considered to be the temporal dimension. Consider a batch of 32 video samples, where each sample is a 128x128 RGB image with channels_last data format, across 10 timesteps. The batch input shape is (32, 10, 128, 128, 3). You can then use TimeDistributed to apply the same Conv2D layer to each of the 10 timesteps, independently:

Name: UnitNormalization Layer
Description: Unit normalization layer. Normalize a batch of inputs so that each input in the batch has a L2 norm equal to 1 (across the axes specified in axis).

Name: UpSampling1D Layer
Description: Upsampling layer for 1D inputs. Repeats each temporal step size times along the time axis.

Name: UpSampling2D Layer
Description: Upsampling layer for 2D inputs. Repeats the rows and columns of the data by size[0] and size[1] respectively.

Name: UpSampling3D Layer
Description: Upsampling layer for 3D inputs.

Name: Wrapper Layer
Description: Abstract wrapper base class. Wrappers take another layer and augment it in various ways. Do not use this class as a layer, it is only an abstract base class. Two usable wrappers are the TimeDistributed and Bidirectional wrappers.

Name: ZeroPadding1D Layer
Description: Zero-padding layer for 1D input (e.g. temporal sequence).

Name: ZeroPadding2D Layer
Description: Zero-padding layer for 2D input (e.g. picture). This layer can add rows and columns of zeros at the top, bottom, left and right side of an image tensor.

Name: ZeroPadding3D Layer
Description: Zero-padding layer for 3D data (spatial or spatio-temporal).

Name: Bias
Description: Systematic error introduced into sampling or testing by selecting or encouraging one outcome or answer over others.

Name: Systemic Bias
Description: Biases resulting from procedures and practices of particular institutions that operate in ways which result in certain social groups being advantaged or favored and others being disadvantaged or devalued.

Name: Historical Bias
Description: Long-standing biases encoded in society over time, distinct from biases in historical description or the interpretation of history, such as viewing the larger world from a Western or European perspective.

Name: Societal Bias
Description: Bias characterized by being for or against groups or individuals based on social identities, demographic factors, or immutable physical characteristics, often manifesting as stereotypes.

Name: Institutional Bias
Description: Bias exhibited at the level of entire institutions, where practices or norms result in the favoring or disadvantaging of certain social groups, such as institutional racism or sexism.

Name: Human Bias
Description: Systematic errors in human thought based on heuristic principles, leading to simplified judgmental operations.

Name: Group Bias
Synomyms: In-group Favoritism|In-group–out-group Bias|In-group bias|Intergroup bias|In-group preference
Description: Favoring members of one's in-group over out-group members, expressed in evaluation, resource allocation, and other ways.

Name: Groupthink Bias
Description: A psychological phenomenon where people in a group make non-optimal decisions due to a desire to conform or fear of dissent.

Name: Funding Bias
Description: Bias arising when biased results are reported to support or satisfy the funding agency or financial supporter of a research study.

Name: Deployment Bias
Description: Arises when systems are used as decision aids for humans, since the human intermediary may act on predictions in ways that are typically not modeled in the system. However, it is still individuals using the deployed system.

Name: Sunk Cost Fallacy Bias
Description: The tendency to continue an endeavor due to previously invested resources, despite costs outweighing benefits.

Name: Individual Bias
Description: A persistent point of view or limited list of such points of view applied by an individual, such as "parent," "academic," or "professional."

Name: Automation Complacency Bias
Description: Over-reliance on automated systems, leading to attenuated human skills, such as with spelling and autocorrect.

Name: Consumer Bias
Description: Bias arising when an algorithm or platform provides users a venue to express their biases, occurring from either side in a digital interaction.

Name: Mode Confusion Bias
Description: When modal interfaces confuse human operators, causing actions appropriate for a different mode but incorrect for the current situation.

Name: Cognitive Bias
Description: Systematic deviation from rational judgment and decision-making, including adaptive mental shortcuts known as heuristics.

Name: Anchoring Bias
Description: The influence of a reference point or anchor on decisions, leading to insufficient adjustment from that anchor point.

Name: Availability Heuristic Bias
Description: A mental shortcut where easily recalled information is overweighted in judgment and decision-making.

Name: Confirmation Bias
Description: The tendency to prefer information that confirms existing beliefs, influencing the search for, interpretation of, and recall of information.

Name: Dunning-Kruger Effect Bias
Description: The tendency of people with low ability in an area to overestimate their self-assessed ability, often measured by comparing self-assessment with objective performance.

Name: Implicit Bias
Description: Unconscious beliefs, attitudes, feelings, associations, or stereotypes that affect information processing, decision-making, and actions.

Name: Loss Of Situational Awareness Bias
Description: When automation leads to humans being unaware of their situation, making them unprepared to assume control in cooperative systems.

Name: User Interaction Bias
Description: Bias arising when a user imposes their own biases during interaction with data, output, results, etc.

Name: Behavioral Bias
Description: Systematic distortions in user behavior across platforms or contexts, or across users represented in different datasets.

Name: Interpretation Bias
Description: A form of information processing bias where users interpret algorithmic outputs according to their internalized biases and views.

Name: Rashomon Effect Bias
Description: Differences in perspective, memory, recall, interpretation, and reporting of the same event by multiple persons or witnesses.

Name: Selective Adherence Bias
Description: The tendency to selectively adopt algorithmic advice that matches pre-existing beliefs and stereotypes.

Name: Streetlight Effect Bias
Description: Bias where people search only where it is easiest to look.

Name: Annotator Reporting Bias
Description: When users rely on automation as a heuristic replacement for their own information seeking and processing.

Name: Human Reporting Bias
Description: When users rely on automation as a heuristic replacement for their own information seeking and processing.

Name: Presentation Bias
Description: Bias arising from how information is presented on the Web, via a user interface, due to rating or ranking of output, or through users' self-selected, biased interaction.

Name: Ranking Bias
Description: The idea that top-ranked results are the most relevant and important, leading to more clicks than other results.

Name: Computational Bias
Description: Systematic tendency causing differences between results and facts in the process of data analysis, including the source of data, the estimator chosen, and analysis methods.

Name: Processing Bias
Description: Judgment modulated by affect, influenced by the level of efficacy and efficiency in information processing; often referred to as aesthetic judgment in cognitive sciences.

Name: Amplification Bias
Description: Bias arising when the distribution over prediction outputs is skewed compared to the prior distribution of the prediction target.

Name: Inherited Bias
Description: Bias arising when machine learning applications generate inputs for other machine learning algorithms, passing on any existing bias.

Name: Error Propagation Bias
Description: The effect of variables' uncertainties (or errors, more specifically random errors) on the uncertainty of a function based on them.

Name: Model Selection Bias
Description: Bias introduced when using data to select a single "best" model from many, or when an explanatory variable has a weak relationship with the response variable.

Name: Survivorship Bias
Description: The tendency to focus on items, observations, or people that "survive" a selection process, overlooking those that did not.

Name: Use And Interpretation Bias
Description: Bias inappropriately analyzing ambiguous stimuli, scenarios, and events.

Name: Hostile Attribution Bias
Description: Bias where individuals perceive benign or ambiguous behaviors as hostile.

Name: Activity Bias
Description: Selection bias occurring when systems/platforms get training data from their most active users, rather than less active or inactive users.

Name: Concept Drift Bias
Description: Bias due to the use of a system outside its planned domain of application, causing performance gaps between laboratory settings and the real world.

Name: Emergent Bias
Description: Bias resulting from the use and reliance on algorithms across new or unanticipated contexts.

Name: Content Production Bias
Description: Bias from structural, lexical, semantic, and syntactic differences in user-generated content.

Name: Data Dredging Bias
Description: Statistical bias where testing many hypotheses in a dataset may yield apparent statistical significance even when results are nonsignificant.

Name: Feedback Loop Bias
Description: Effects occurring when an algorithm learns from user behavior and feeds that behavior back into the model.

Name: Linking Bias
Description: Bias arising when network attributes obtained from user connections, activities, or interactions misrepresent true user behavior.

Name: Selection And Sampling Bias
Description: Bias introduced by non-random selection of individuals, groups, or data, failing to ensure representativeness.

Name: Data Generation Bias
Description: Bias from adding synthetic or redundant data samples to a dataset.

Name: Detection Bias
Description: Systematic differences between groups in how outcomes are determined, potentially over- or underestimating effect size.

Name: Ecological Fallacy Bias
Description: Bias occurring when an inference about an individual is made based on their group membership.

Name: Evaluation Bias
Description: Bias arising when testing populations do not equally represent user populations or when inappropriate performance metrics are used.

Name: Exclusion Bias
Description: Bias occurring when specific groups of user populations are excluded from testing and analysis.

Name: Measurement Bias
Description: Bias arising when features and labels are proxies for desired quantities, potentially leading to differential performance.

Name: Popularity Bias
Description: Selection bias where more popular items are more exposed, under-representing less popular items.

Name: Population Bias
Description: Systematic distortions in demographics or other user characteristics between represented users and the target population.

Name: Representation Bias
Description: Bias due to non-random sampling of subgroups, making trends non-generalizable to new populations.

Name: Simpon's Paradox Bias
Description: A statistical phenomenon where the association between two variables changes when controlling for another variable.

Name: Temporal Bias
Description: Bias arising from differences in populations and behaviors over time.

Name: Uncertainty Bias
Description: Bias favoring groups better represented in training data, due to less prediction uncertainty.

Name: Machine Learning
Description: A field of inquiry devoted to understanding and building methods that learn from data to improve performance on a set of tasks.

Name: Multimodal Learning
Description: A type of deep learning that uses multiple modalities of data, such as text, audio, and images, to improve learning outcomes.

Name: Meta-Learning
Description: Methods for creating automatic learning algorithms that learn from metadata about machine learning experiments.

Name: Transfer Learning
Description: Methods that reuse or transfer information from previously learned tasks to facilitate the learning of new tasks.

Name: Active Learning
Description: Methods that interactively query a user or another information source to label new data points with the desired outputs.

Name: Ensemble Learning
Description: Methods that use multiple learning algorithms to achieve better predictive performance than any of the constituent algorithms alone.

Name: Reinforcement Learning
Description: Methods that do not require labeled input/output pairs or explicit correction of sub-optimal actions, focusing instead on balancing exploration and exploitation to optimize performance over time.

Name: Unsupervised Learning
Description: Algorithms that learn patterns from unlabeled data.

Name: Supervised Learning
Description: Methods that learn a function mapping input to output based on example input-output pairs.

Name: Decision Tree
Description: A decision support tool that uses a tree-like model of decisions and their possible consequences, including chance event outcomes, resource costs, and utilities.

Name: Random Forest
Description: An ensemble learning method for classification, regression, and other tasks that constructs a multitude of decision trees during training.

Name: Association Rule Learning
Description: A rule-based machine learning method for discovering interesting relations between variables in large databases.

Name: Clustering
Description: Methods that group a set of objects such that objects in the same group are more similar to each other than to those in other groups.

Name: Biclustering
Description: Methods that simultaneously cluster the rows and columns of a matrix to identify submatrices with coherent patterns.

Name: Unsupervised Clustering
Description: Methods that group a set of unlabeled objects such that objects in the same group are more similar to each other than to those in other groups.

Name: Unsupervised Biclustering
Description: Methods that simultaneously cluster the rows and columns of an unlabeled input matrix to identify submatrices with coherent patterns.

Name: Supervised Clustering
Description: Methods that group labeled objects such that objects in the same group have similar labels, relative to those in other groups.

Name: Supervised Biclustering
Synomyms: Supervised Block Clustering|Supervised Co-clustering|Supervised Two-mode Clustering|Supervised Two-way Clustering|Supervised Joint Clustering
Description: Methods that simultaneously cluster the rows and columns of a labeled matrix, considering data labels to enhance cluster coherence.

Name: Dimensionality Reduction
Description: The process of transforming data from a high-dimensional space into a lower-dimensional space while retaining meaningful properties of the original data.

Name: Generalized Linear Model
Description: A model that generalizes linear regression by relating the linear model to the response variable via a link function and allowing the variance of each measurement to be a function of its predicted value.

Name: Regression Analysis
Description: A set of statistical processes for estimating the relationships between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables.

Name: Natural Language Processing
Description: A subfield of linguistics, computer science, and artificial intelligence focused on the interactions between computers and human language, including programming computers to process and analyze large amounts of natural language data.

Name: Binary Classification
Description: Methods that classify elements into two groups based on a classification rule.

Name: Multiclass Classification
Description: Methods that classify instances into one of three or more classes.

Name: Classification
Description: Methods that distinguish and distribute kinds of "things" into different groups.

Name: Hierarchical Classification
Description: Methods that group things according to a hierarchy.

Name: Time Series Analysis
Description: Methods for analyzing time series data to extract meaningful statistics and characteristics.

Name: Time Series Forecasting
Description: Methods that predict future values based on previously observed values.

Name: K-nearest Neighbor Algorithm
Description: An algorithm that groups objects by a plurality vote of its neighbors, assigning each object to the class most common among its k nearest neighbors.

Name: K-nearest Neighbor Classification Algorithm
Description: An algorithm that classifies objects by a plurality vote of its neighbors, assigning each object to the class most common among its k nearest neighbors.

Name: K-nearest Neighbor Regression Algorithm
Description: An algorithm that assigns the average of the values of k nearest neighbors to objects.

Name: Hierarchical Clustering
Description: Methods that build a hierarchy of clusters.

Name: Logistic Regression
Description: A statistical model that estimates the probability of an event occurring by modeling the log-odds of the event as a linear combination of one or more independent variables.

Name: Lasso Regression
Description: A regression analysis method that performs both variable selection and regularization to enhance prediction accuracy and interpretability.

Name: Ridge Regression
Description: A method of estimating the coefficients of multiple regression models in scenarios where the independent variables are highly correlated.

Name: Probabilistic Graphical Model
Description: A probabilistic model in which a graph expresses the conditional dependence structure between random variables.

Name: Causal Graphical Model
Synomyms: Casaul Graph|Path Diagram|Casaul Bayesian Network|DAG|Directed Acyclic Graph
Description: Probabilistic graphical models used to encode assumptions about the data-generating process.

Name: Probabilistic Topic Model
Description: Methods that use statistical techniques to analyze the words in each text to discover common themes, their connections, and their changes over time.

Name: Linear Regression
Description: A linear approach for modeling the relationship between a scalar response and one or more explanatory variables.

Name: Spatial Regression
Description: A regression method used to model spatial relationships.

Name: Survival Analysis
Description: Methods for analyzing the expected duration of time until one or more events occur, such as death in biological organisms or failure in mechanical systems.

Name: Proportional Hazards Model
Description: A survival modeling method where the unique effect of a unit increase in a covariate is multiplicative with respect to the hazard rate.

Name: Least-squares Analysis
Description: A standard approach in regression analysis to approximate the solution of overdetermined systems by minimizing the sum of the squares of the residuals.

Name: Principal Component Analysis
Description: A method for analyzing large datasets with high-dimensional features per observation, increasing data interpretability while preserving maximum information and enabling visualization of multidimensional data.

Name: t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor embedding
Description: A statistical method for visualizing high-dimensional data by giving each datapoint a location in a two or three-dimensional map.

Name: Multidimensional Scaling
Description: A method that translates information about the pairwise distances among a set of objects or individuals into a configuration of points mapped into an abstract Cartesian space.

Name: Manifold Learning
Description: Methods based on the assumption that observed data lie on a low-dimensional manifold embedded in a higher-dimensional space.

Name: Data Imputation
Description: Methods that replace missing data with substituted values.

Name: Fixed Effects Model
Description: A statistical model in which the model parameters are fixed or non-random quantities.

Name: Random Effects Model
Description: A statistical model where the model parameters are random variables.

Name: Self-supervised Learning
Description: Regarded as an intermediate form between supervised and unsupervised learning, self-supervised learning involves predicting parts of the input data from other observed parts without relying on human-annotated labels.

Name: Large Language Model
Description: A language model consisting of a neural network with many parameters (typically billions of weights or more), trained on large quantities of unlabeled text using self-supervised learning or semi-supervised learning.

Name: Encoder LLM
Description: An encoder-only architecture that encodes the input sequence into a fixed-length representation, which is then used as input to a classifier or regressor for prediction. The model has a pre-trained general-purpose encoder that requires fine-tuning for specific tasks.

Name: Decoder LLM
Description: A decoder-only architecture consisting of only a decoder, trained to predict the next token in a sequence given the previous tokens. Unlike the encoder-decoder architecture, it does not have an explicit encoder and encodes information implicitly in the hidden state of the decoder, updated at each step of the generation process.

Name: Encoder-Decoder LLM
Description: The original transformer architecture introduced in the "Attention Is All You Need" paper.
